intro: Robinsonella pilosa, commonly known as the hairy balsam, is a herbaceous annual plant native to the southern United States. It belongs to the family Violaceae and is characterized by its hairy stems and oval, lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces clusters of small, pale purple to white flowers that bloom in late summer. Its leaves are often covered in fine, stiff hairs, giving it a distinctive appearance. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in disturbed habitats such as roadsides and fields.
